text:
Population

Definition: A collection of objects of interest in a study
Studying who will win an upcoming mayoral election

Population: Everyone who are planning to vote

Studying the defect rate of a cellphone screen from a manufacturer

Population: All the cellphone screens made by the manufacturer

title: 1.2 Population, sample, and variable
text:
Sample

Definition: A subset of the population selected by a defined procedure
Studying who will win an upcoming mayoral election

Sample: An telephone poll of 500 randomly selected potential voters

Studying the defect rate of a cellphone screen from a manufacturer

Sample: 200 randomly selected screens for inspection

Continuous variables
The variable takes infinitely many, uncountable values.

The water level of dam
The speed of riding a bicycle
The time when an order arrives at a shop


If it can take on two particular real values, it can also take on all real values between them.



If you can count it, it is discrete.
If you need to measure it, it is continuous.

title: 1.5 Measures of location
text:
Sample mean
For a given set of \(n\) numbers
\[x_1, x_2, \cdots, x_n\]

the sample mean \(\bar{x}\) is given by
\[\bar{x} = \frac{1}{n}(x_1 + x_2 + \cdots + x_n)\]


We often use the shorthand sigma notation
\[\bar{x} = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n x_i\]

title: 1.5 Measures of location
text:
Sample mean
\[12, 34, 14, 5, 44, 28, 22, 19, 36, 25\]

\[\bar{x} = \frac{1}{10}(12 + 34 + \cdots + 25)=23.9\]



Interpretation: the center of gravity for a series of weights positioned at the specified values in a dot plot.

title: 1.5 Measures of location
text:
In a startup company of 10 people
9 employees earn a salary of $50k a year each
The CEO earns $550k a year


\[50, 50, 50, 50, 50, 50, 50, 50, 50, 550\]


\[\bar{x} = \frac{1}{10}(50\times9 + 550\times1)=100\]

One may argue that $100k is not a ‚Äútypical‚Äù value.

title: 1.5 Measures of location
text:
Sample median
The median, \(\tilde{x}\) (reads x tilde), is the middle value in a set of data that is arranged in order.
If the sample size \(n\) is an even number, there are two middle values.
\[1, 3, 4, 6, 8, 9\]
\(\tilde{x}\) is the average of the two.

title: 1.5 Measures of location
text:
Exercise
Data set:
\[12, 34, 14, 5, 44, 28, 22, 19, 36, 25\]

Sort the data to order:
\[5, 12, 14, 19, 22, 25, 28, 34, 36, 44\]


\[\tilde{x} = \frac{1}{2}(22+25)=23.5\]


Interpretation: half of the data are smaller than 23.5, half are larger than 23.5.

title: 1.5 Measures of location
text:
The earlier example

In a company of ten people,
Nine employees earn a salary of .red[$50k] a year each;
The CEO earns .red[$550k] a year.


\[50, 50, 50, 50, 50, 50, 50, 50, 50, 550\]


\[\tilde{x} = \frac{1}{2}(50 + 50)=50\]

The median of $50k is arguably more ‚Äútypical‚Äù.

The median is less sensitive to outliers.

title: 1.5 Measures of location
text:
Quartiles & percentiles

First quartile (25th percentile)

Separating the bottom 25% data from the top 75%
The middle value between the smallest and median.

Second quartile (50th percentile, or simply, the median)

Separating the bottom 50% data from the top 50%

Third quartile (75th percentile)

Separating the bottom 75% data from the top 25%
The middle value between the median and largest.

title: 1.5 Measures of location
text:
Trimmed mean
The mean after discarding the smallest & largest \(\alpha\%\) of the data

Dive scores from 7 judges:
\[4, 6, 6, 6, 7, 7, 8\]


The lowest and highest scores are eliminated.
\[6, 6, 6, 7, 7\]


The remaining scores are totaled.
\[6+6+6+7+7=32\]

title: 1.5 Measures of location
text:
Trimmed mean
Typically \(\alpha\%\) is between 5 to 25%.
When discarding the bottom 25% and top 25%, it is called the interquartile mean.


The sample mean and median can be considered as two special cases of trimmed mean.

\(\alpha\%=0\%\)

Discard no data: mean

\(\alpha\%=50\%\)

Discard all but the middle number(s): median
